rounds.observation:
[GAME] You are Player 0 in a 2-player Texas Hold'em Poker game.
Game Information:
- 10 hands total
- Starting stack: 1000 chips
- Blinds: 10/20

Available actions (exact tokens):
  '[Check]'  - when no bet is live
  '[Call]'   - match the current bet
  '[Fold]'   - discard your hand
  '[Bet N]'  - open for N chips
  '[Raise N]'- raise by N chips

Invalid actions will result in retries. Use exact bracket format and ensure you have sufficient chips for bets/raises. Check when facing a bet is invalid.
[GAME] Starting a new 10-round Texas Hold'em game with 2 players.
[GAME] ===== Hand 1 / 10 - Pre‑flop =====
Pot: 30 | Current bet: 20
Visible board: []
P0 (Dealer/BB): 990.00 chips | bet 10.00 | active
P1 (SB): 980.00 chips | bet 20.00 | active
Your hole: 9♣, K♥
==============================================
rounds.response:
Preflop Analysis  
- Position: I’m the Big Blind, so I act last pre-flop (even heads-up OOP in every later street, but pre-flop I see P1’s action first).  
- Pot size: 30 chips (20 from P1 small blind, 10 from me Big Blind).  
- Villain’s actions so far: he only posted the 20; no raise. He hasn’t bet anything extra yet.  
- Hand strength: K♥ 9♣ offsuit is not premium, but ahead of a lot of limping / stealing ranges heads-up and has good board coverage with a King blocker.  
- SPR if flatting is pot of 40 with effective stacks of 980. Easy playability post-flop.

Decision: I want to raise for value now to build a pot, deny some equity from random hands, and deny free equity from low cards. A sensible size is around 60–70 chips (3–3.5× the SB’s 20). I’ll pick 70; it’s large enough to pressure more holdings without risking an outsized chunk of stack early in the session.

[Action to send]
[Raise 70]
